Award.AwardTitle: STARS: Sycamore Technology Academics & Recruitment Scholarships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is providing 20 scholarships to academically talented and financially needy students at in two baccalaureate degree engineering technology programs (Computer Engineering Technology and Mechanical Engineering Technology) at Indiana State University (ISU). The project develops new support mechanisms including multi-disciplinary seminars, industry forum, and online academic/social networking to compliment mature student support services, such as learning community and co-ops/interns. Interactions among students and industry professionals help increase the focus and interest of students, enhance the educational experience of students, and build a relationship of feedback and exchange for students' ongoing success. Women and underrepresented minorities are also being recruited as participants of the project. An independent evaluator is involved in project evaluation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF/S-STEM grant (STARS project) period, overall enrollment in the BS Mechanical Engineering Technology (MET) program increased from 126 to 278 and Computer Engineering Technology (CET) program from 53 to 90. Indiana State Univeisty became an improtant school in the state of Indiana for engineering technology majors. First year retention rate in the MET program increased from 76% to 80% while in the CET program it fluctuated between 47% and 68%. 4-year graduation rate in the MET program increased from 25% to 34% and in the CET program it stayed about 25%.

Project helped in preparing and producing workforce in STEM fields in the state of Indiana. Many of our graduates are employed in Indiana and are contirbuting to the state and country economy.

STARS project assisted talented but economically disadvantaged students graduating with a degree in STEM field, Particulalry, the project impacted first generation and underrepresented students very positively. Several of students who received the scholarship would have otherwise faced difficulty in completing their study resulting in drop out or delayed graduation.

The project provided an excellent netwroking oportunity to the scholarship recipients with professional societies in their field like ASME and IEEE. Also, several industry speakers were invited to speak with the students to motivate them for a career in STEM field.


Last Modified: 08/24/2016
Modified by: M. Affan Badar
